message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The disproportionate growth suggests a skeletal dysplasia, and the mode of inheritance is most likely autosomal dominant since there is no gender preference and neither parent needs to be affected. The other options do not fit the pattern of inheritance seen in this disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical exam findings suggest achondroplasia, a genetic disorder that follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. This means that only one copy of the mutated gene is necessary for the disorder to be expressed. X-linked dominant and X-linked recessive patterns of inheritance are less likely as they often affect males more than females, and mitochondrial pattern of inheritance is characterized by maternal transmission.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of disproportionate growth, rhizomelic shortening of the extremities, and normal intelligence point towards achondroplasia, which is an autosomal dominant disorder. X-linked recessive inheritance would show a different pattern of inheritance and mitochondrial inheritance would not have affected the child's growth patterns.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The characteristics of disproportionate growth and delayed motor milestones suggest a form of dwarfism. Among the options, only Autosomal dominant inheritance is consistent with the presentation described. X-linked recessive and dominant are sex-linked and would not present in the same way in females. Mitochondrial inheritance is not associated with this type of disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description and presentation of the disorder match achondroplasia, which is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means that the affected individual has a 50% chance of passing on the gene to each of their children.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The disproportionate growth pattern and delayed motor milestones suggest a skeletal dysplasia disorder, and among the options, only autosomal dominant inheritance is known to cause skeletal dysplasia. X-linked recessive is more common for disorders affecting only males. X-linked dominant is rare and only causes moderate to severe intellectual disability. Mitochondrial pattern of inheritance only affects maternal transmission.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The disproportionate growth and rhizomelic pattern of shortening suggest achondroplasia, which is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. X-linked recessive inheritance would only occur if the affected gene was on an X chromosome, and there is no indication of this. X-linked dominant inheritance would also not account for the pattern of inheritance seen in this case. Mitochondrial pattern of inheritance would only occur if the affected gene was in the mitochondria, and there is no indication of this either.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of disproportionate growth with both upper and lower extremities showing rhizomelic shortening suggests achondroplasia, which is an autosomal dominant disorder. X-linked recessive inheritance refers to conditions where males are more frequently affected, which is not the case here. X-linked dominant disorders are rare and often lethal in males. Mitochondrial inheritance would require involvement of the mother as the primary source of genetic material, which is not indicated in the question stem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description matches the features of achondroplasia, which is an autosomal dominant disorder. The head circumference to height ratio being high but the axial skeleton being normal are characteristic. Delayed motor milestones can be a result of skeletal abnormalities. The other options are not associated with achondroplasia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of disproportionate growth suggests a skeletal dysplasia, specifically achondroplasia, which is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. X-linked recessive and dominant patterns of inheritance are more commonly associated with other types of disorders, and mitochondrial pattern of inheritance is not typically associated with skeletal dysplasias.
